awd_titl_txt: RII Track 1: Materials Assembly and Design Excellence in South Carolina: MADE in SC
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description
The initiative for Materials Assembly and Design Excellence in South Carolina (MADE in SC) promises to break new ground in advanced materials design. The project will combine computational and experimental methods to design materials with specific desirable properties. The project will advance fundamental knowledge of complex materials while simultaneously working toward the development of products with valuable commercial applications, such as improved lasers, water treatment, and regenerative medicine. The project will make major investments in South Carolina?s research capacity, acquiring state-of-the art instrumentation and computing capabilities and hiring seventeen new faculty researchers at institutions across the state.  In parallel with its research agenda, MADE in SC will also work to improve Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education capacity in South Carolina through college curriculum improvements and professional development activities for high school teachers.

Technical Description 
MADE in SC materials development process will use a Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) framework, incorporating an iterative design loop wherein modeling and computation based on initial design constraints provide data that will inform experimental design. Imaging and data visualization of experimental results will lead to insights that can then drive additional modeling work, with the cycle continuing until an optimal solution is achieved.  This MGI-based framework will depend on the resources of the Multiscale Modeling and Computational Core (MCC), which will be established as part of the project.  The MCC will develop modeling capabilities appropriate across length scales (microscopic, mesoscopic, and continuum), and will support the application of these tools to the project?s major research thrusts: 1) hierarchical structures with controlled optical and magnetic properties; 2) stimuli-responsive polymeric materials; and 3) rational design of interactive biomaterials.  These research efforts will advance fundamental understanding of the chemical and physical drivers of observed material properties while also realizing new materials with desirable properties for commercial applications.

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Materials Assembly and Design Excellence in South Carolina (MADE in SC) was focused on discovering and establishing new and sustainable approaches for the design and assembly of hierarchical materials at multiple length scales to serve SC’s STEM research, education and workforce needs and invigorate economic development. Research focused on three synergistic thrusts: intelligently designed inorganic materials; stimuli-responsive polymeric materials; and interactive biomaterials. A common Multiscale Modeling and Computation Core (MCC) served as the underlying research foundation for the project (Figure 1). All projects used the materials discovery and development paradigm from the national Materials Genome Initiative (MGI, Figure 2).

MADE in SC was a partnership of three Comprehensive Research Universities (CRUs), four Predominantly Undergraduate/two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (PUIs/HBCUs) and one technical college.

The overarching goals were to:

  • Discover/develop new inorganic materials, stimuli-responsive polymeric materials, and interactive biomaterials.
  • Improve SC’s research infrastructure, developing state-of-the-art facilities while recruiting 17 faculty with complementary expertise.
  • Increase the pipeline of graduate and undergraduate students, mentor postdocs and provide statewide K-12 outreach.
  • Engage industry to establish a jurisdiction-wide consortium to support SC’s evolving technical/personnel needs in advanced materials.
  • Promote interdisciplinary collaborations.
  • Promote diversity in education and workforce development.
  • Implement research, education, diversity, and outreach activities with internal and external stakeholders.

The project successfully met each of these goals, with the following outcomes:

Intellectual Merit

  1. Advanced materials research enhancing the reputation of institutions and faculty members: New materials, synthesis techniques, simulation approaches and understanding in all focus areas (Figure 1) was reflected in 231 manuscripts. The average impact factor of the publication journals is 6.17, and papers published in Years 1 -3 (Oct 2017 - Sept 2021) have, on average, achieved an impressive 23.4 citations each. 
  2. Research programs using MGI approach: The MGI paradigm (Figure 2) was articulated and resources provided such that over the final 3 years, all research projects used this approach to effectively couple theory/simulations/data science with experimental research, supporting efficient materials discovery.
  3. Broadening participation in materials research: Sixty research groups contributed to research, 30% led by PUI/HBCU faculty (Figure 3) who also led approximately 18% of publications.  During the award, over 30 additional faculty contributed to the program. Seed Funding totaling $2.2M awarded to all institution types to catalyze new research enabled the inclusion of five additional PUIs.
  4. Collaborations and partnerships: External partnerships with National Labs, international collaborators, and academic institutions outside MADE in SC were reported in 50% of publications. Inter-disciplinary and/or inter-institutional collaborations within MADE in SC were reported in 22% of publications (Figures 3 (b) and 4).
  5. Research infrastructure improvement: Investment of $3.2M in materials research equipment at seven institutions (three CRUs and four PUIs) is being used to sustain future materials research in SC.
  6. Sustainability: Materials research was supplemented by successfully securing over $111M in additional funding, including four NSF RUI, three NSF REU, a DOE EFRC; six NSF MRI, an S-STEM; four NSF CAREER, two NSF Bridge to Doctorate, two NIH R01, one NIH R21 and two NSF DMREF awards.
  7. Translational research: MADE in SC faculty members served as co-investigators on 63 patent disclosures (20 granted and three licensed).

Broader Impact

  1. Engagement of researchers at all levels: Broad engagement was realized, incorporating 90 faculty, 24 post-docs, over 140 distinct graduate students (some contributing multiple years), and over 190 undergraduates.
  2. Inclusive faculty excellence: Faculty diversity within advanced materials research/education was increased, hiring 17 new faculty through MADE in SC across five institutions (three CRUs, one PUI, one HBCU). Six new faculty (35%) were hired from groups underrepresented in their fields, including five at CRUs.  
  3. Broadening participation: Over $280,000 was invested in 29 Scientific Advocacy awards supporting diversity initiatives in STEM at the K-12, undergraduate and graduate level statewide. Additional diversity initiatives were developed through institutional commitments (Winthrop) and externally funded programs (Furman). The first Bridges to the Doctorate programs were offered at Clemson and UofSC, with Clemson’s program focused on advanced materials. Summer materials science camps engaged 38 HS teachers, including a new Professional Development course in Materials at Winthrop. Six-week research experiences engaged 30 teachers, predominantly from SC high schools serving underrepresented and/or low-income students.
  4. Curriculum development: New MGI curricula were developed and delivered at 2-year, 4-year and R1 institutions.
  5. Partnership with industry: Forty new research and educational partnerships were established between academic institutions and industry to serve the SC economy.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Prakash Nagarkatti

The Materials Assembly and Design Excellence in South Carolina (MADE in SC) was focused on discovering and establishing new and sustainable approaches for the design and assembly of hierarchical materials at multiple length scales to serve SCs STEM research, education and workforce needs and invigorate economic development. Research focused on three synergistic thrusts: intelligently designed inorganic materials; stimuli-responsive polymeric materials; and interactive biomaterials. Discover/develop new inorganic materials, stimuli-responsive polymeric materials, and interactive biomaterials.
Improve SCs research infrastructure, developing state-of-the-art facilities while recruiting 17 faculty with complementary expertise.
Increase the pipeline of graduate and undergraduate students, mentor postdocs and provide statewide K-12 outreach.

The project successfully met each of these goals, with the following outcomes:

Advanced materials research enhancing the reputation of      institutions and faculty members: New materials, synthesis techniques, simulation      approaches and understanding in all focus areas (Figure 1) was reflected      in 231 manuscripts. The average impact factor of the publication journals      is 6.17, and papers published in Years 1 -3 (Oct 2017 - Sept 2021) have,      on average, achieved an impressive 23.4 citations each. 
Research programs using MGI approach: The MGI paradigm (Figure      2) was articulated and resources provided such that over the final 3      years, all research projects used this approach to effectively couple      theory/simulations/data science with experimental research, supporting efficient      materials discovery.
Broadening participation in materials research: Sixty research groups      contributed to research, 30% led by PUI/HBCU faculty (Figure 3) who also      led approximately 18% of publications.      During the award, over 30 additional faculty contributed to the program.      Seed Funding totaling $2.2M awarded to all institution types to catalyze      new research enabled the inclusion of five additional PUIs.
Collaborations and partnerships: External partnerships with      National Labs, international collaborators, and academic institutions      outside MADE in SC were reported in 50% of publications.      Inter-disciplinary and/or inter-institutional collaborations within MADE      in SC were reported in 22% of publications (Figures 3 (b) and 4). 
Research infrastructure improvement: Investment of $3.2M in      materials research equipment at seven institutions (three CRUs and four      PUIs) is being used to sustain future materials research in SC.
Sustainability: Materials research was supplemented by successfully securing      over $111M in additional funding, including four NSF RUI, three NSF REU, a      DOE EFRC; six NSF MRI, an S-STEM; four NSF CAREER, two NSF Bridge to      Doctorate, two NIH R01, one NIH R21 and two NSF DMREF awards.

Broader Impact

Engagement of researchers at all levels: Broad engagement was realized,      incorporating 90 faculty, 24 post-docs, over 140 distinct graduate      students (some contributing multiple years), and over 190 undergraduates.
Inclusive faculty excellence: Faculty diversity      within advanced materials research/education was increased, hiring 17 new      faculty through MADE in SC across five institutions (three CRUs, one PUI, one      HBCU). Six new faculty (35%) were hired from groups underrepresented in      their fields, including five at CRUs. 
Broadening participation: Over $280,000 was invested      in 29 Scientific Advocacy awards supporting diversity initiatives in STEM at      the K-12, undergraduate and graduate level statewide. Additional diversity      initiatives were developed through institutional commitments (Winthrop)      and externally funded programs (Furman). The      first Bridges to the Doctorate programs were offered at Clemson and UofSC,      with Clemsons program focused on advanced materials. Summer      materials science camps engaged 38 HS teachers, including a new      Professional Development course in Materials at Winthrop. Six-week      research experiences engaged 30 teachers, predominantly from SC high      schools serving underrepresented and/or low-income students.
Curriculum development: New MGI curricula were developed      and delivered at 2-year, 4-year and R1 institutions.
Partnership with industry: Forty new research and      educational partnerships were established between academic institutions      and industry to serve the SC economy.
